article.title: SDSS-IV MaNGA: Constraints on the Conditions for Star Formation in Galaxy Discs

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the radial profiles of Qthermal (blue) and τ (orange) in the top panels of Figure 3 suggest about the onset of star formation in galaxy disks?
choices: Disks reach the threshold for self-shielding before becoming gravitationally unstable.
The presence of a stellar component has a negligible impact on disk stability.
Disks become gravitationally unstable at much larger radii than where they become self-shielded.
Star formation only occurs in regions where the disk is both self-shielded and gravitationally unstable.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 4a, what does the trend of decreasing Qthermalt with decreasing Σ∗ (indicated by color) suggest?
choices: Gas-rich disks are more likely to be self-shielded than gas-poor disks.
The stellar component of a galaxy disk has a stabilizing effect against fragmentation.
Star formation is less efficient in the presence of a strong stellar component.
The N2O2 metallicity calibration likely underestimates the true gas-phase metallicity.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 5 shows the distribution of gas fraction (fg) as a function of stellar surface density (Σ∗). What can be concluded from this figure?
choices: Gas fraction is independent of stellar surface density.
The gas fraction needed to dominate the disk surface density increases with increasing stellar surface density.
All galaxies with high stellar surface densities have low gas fractions.
Most star-forming galaxies are dominated by their gas mass.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the distribution of data points in Figure 6f, particularly the lack of points in the upper right quadrant, suggest about the relationship between gravitational instability and self-shielding?
choices: Galaxies reach the threshold for gravitational instability (Qthermal~1) before reaching the threshold for self-shielding (τ~1).
Self-shielding is a necessary precursor to the onset of widespread star formation.
Star formation is equally likely to occur in both self-shielded and unshielded regions.
The onset of star formation is not correlated with either gravitational instability or self-shielding.

multiple_choice_question.text: Equation 5 provides an approximate upper limit for Qthermalt. What is the primary reason this equation can overestimate the true value of Qthermalt?
choices: It assumes all gas has a temperature of 104 K.
It does not account for the contribution of the stellar component to disk stability.
It utilizes a simplified model for the vertical structure of the gas disk.
It relies on strong-line metallicity calibrations, which have inherent uncertainties.
